Culture.
Emirati culture is based on <a href="Arabian%20culture">Arabian culture</a> and has been influenced by the cultures of <a href="Persians">Persia</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, and <a href="East%20Africa">East Africa</a>. Arabian and <a href="Persian%20architecture">Arabian inspired architecture</a> is part of the expression of the local Emirati identity. Arabian influence on Emirati culture is noticeably visible in traditional Emirati architecture and <a href="folk%20arts">folk arts</a>. For example, the distinctive wind tower which tops traditional Emirati buildings, the "<a href="barjeel">barjeel</a>" has become an identifying mark of Emirati architecture and is attributed to Arabian influence. This influence is derived both from traders who fled the tax regime in Persia in the early 19th century and from Emirati ownership of ports on the Arabian coast, for instance the Al Qassimi port of Lingeh.
The United Arab Emirates has a diverse society. Dubai's economy depends more on international trade and tourism, and is more open to visitors, while Abu Dhabi society is more domestic as the city's economy is focused on fossil fuel extraction.
Major holidays in the United Arab Emirates include "<a href="Eid%20ul-Fitr">Eid al Fitr</a>", which marks the end of "<a href="Ramadan">Ramadan</a>", and <a href="National%20Day%20%28United%20Arab%20Emirates%29">National Day</a> (2 December), which marks the formation of the United Arab Emirates. Emirati males prefer to wear a <a href="thawb">kandura</a>, an ankle-length white tunic woven from wool or cotton, and Emirati women wear an <a href="abaya">abaya</a>, a black over-garment that covers most parts of the body.
Ancient Emirati poetry was strongly influenced by the 8th-century Arab scholar Al Khalil bin Ahmed. The earliest known poet in the UAE is <a href="Ibn%20Majid">Ibn Majid</a>, born between 1432 and 1437 in Ras Al-Khaimah. The most famous Emirati writers were Mubarak Al Oqaili (1880–1954), Salem bin Ali al Owais (1887–1959) and Ahmed bin Sulayem (1905–1976). Three other poets from Sharjah, known as the Hirah group, are observed to have been heavily influenced by the Apollo and <a href="Romantic%20poetry">Romantic poets</a>. The <a href="Sharjah%20International%20Book%20Fair">Sharjah International Book Fair</a> is the oldest and largest in the country.
The <a href="list%20of%20museums%20in%20the%20United%20Arab%20Emirates">list of museums in the United Arab Emirates</a> includes some of regional repute, most famously <a href="Sharjah%20%28city%29">Sharjah</a> with its Heritage District containing 17 museums, which in 1998 was the Cultural Capital of the Arab World. In Dubai, the area of <a href="Al%20Quoz">Al Quoz</a> has attracted a number of art galleries as well as museums such as the <a href="Salsali%20Private%20Museum">Salsali Private Museum</a>. Abu Dhabi has established a culture district on <a href="Saadiyat%20Island">Saadiyat Island</a>. Six grand projects are planned, including the <a href="Guggenheim%20Abu%20Dhabi">Guggenheim Abu Dhabi</a> and the <a href="Louvre%20Abu%20Dhabi">Louvre Abu Dhabi</a>. Dubai also plans to build a <a href="Kunsthal">Kunsthal</a> museum and a district for galleries and artists.
Emirati culture is a part of the <a href="culture%20of%20Eastern%20Arabia">culture of Eastern Arabia</a>. <a href="Liwa%20%28music%29">Liwa</a> is a type of music and dance performed locally, mainly in communities that contain descendants of <a href="Bantu%20peoples">Bantu peoples</a> from the <a href="African%20Great%20Lakes">African Great Lakes</a> region. The <a href="Dubai%20Desert%20Rock%20Festival">Dubai Desert Rock Festival</a> is also another major festival consisting of heavy metal and rock artists. The <a href="cinema%20of%20the%20United%20Arab%20Emirates">cinema of the United Arab Emirates</a> is minimal but expanding.
Cuisine.
The traditional food of the Emirates has always been rice, fish and meat. The people of the United Arab Emirates have adopted most of their foods from other West and South Asian countries including Iran, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, India and Oman. Seafood has been the mainstay of the Emirati diet for centuries. Meat and rice are other staple foods, with <a href="lamb%20and%20mutton">lamb and mutton</a> preferred to goat and beef. Popular beverages are coffee and tea, which can be complemented with <a href="cardamom">cardamom</a>, <a href="saffron">saffron</a>, or <a href="Spearmint">mint</a> to give them a distinctive flavour.
Popular cultural Emirati dishes include "threed", "machboos", "khubisa", "khameer" and "chabab" bread among others while <a href="Lugaimat">Lugaimat</a> is a famous Emirati dessert.
With the influence of western culture, fast food has become very popular among young people, to the extent that campaigns have been held to highlight the dangers of fast food excesses. Alcohol is allowed to be served only in hotel restaurants and bars. All nightclubs are permitted to sell alcohol. Specific supermarkets may sell alcohol, but these products are sold in separate sections. Likewise, pork, which is <a href="haram">haram</a> (not permitted for Muslims), is sold in separate sections in all major supermarkets. Note that although alcohol may be consumed, it is illegal to be intoxicated in public or drive a motor vehicle with any trace of alcohol in the blood.
Sports.
<a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> is particularly popular in the United Arab Emirates, and a Grand Prix is annually held at the <a href="Yas%20Marina%20Circuit">Yas Marina Circuit</a> in <a href="Yas%20Island">Yas Island</a> in Abu Dhabi. The race takes place in the evening, and was the first ever Grand Prix to start in daylight and finish at night. Other popular sports include <a href="camel%20racing">camel racing</a>, <a href="falconry">falconry</a>, <a href="endurance%20riding">endurance riding</a>, and <a href="tennis">tennis</a>. The emirate of <a href="Dubai">Dubai</a> is also home to two major <a href="golf">golf</a> courses: the <a href="Dubai%20Golf%20Club">Dubai Golf Club</a> and <a href="Emirates%20Golf%20Club">Emirates Golf Club</a>.
In the past, child camel jockeys were used, leading to widespread criticism. Eventually, the UAE passed laws banning the use of children for the sport, leading to the prompt removal of almost all child jockeys. Recently robot jockeys have been introduced to overcome the problem of child camel jockeys which was an issue of human rights violations. <a href="Ansar%20Burney">Ansar Burney</a> is often praised for the work he has done in this area.
Football.
<a href="Association%20football">Football</a> is a popular sport in the UAE. <a href="Al-Nasr%20Dubai%20SC">Al Nasr</a>, <a href="Al%20Ain%20Club">Al Ain</a>, <a href="Al%20Wasl%20FC">Al Wasl</a>, <a href="Sharjah%20FC">Sharjah</a>, <a href="Al%20Wahda%20FC">Al Wahda</a>, and <a href="Shabab%20Al-Ahli%20Dubai%20FC">Shabab Al Ahli</a> are the most popular teams and enjoy the reputation of long-time regional champions. The <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20Football%20Association">United Arab Emirates Football Association</a> was established in 1971 and since then has dedicated its time and effort to promoting the game, organising <a href="youth%20program">youth program</a>mes and improving the abilities of not only its players, but also the officials and coaches involved with its regional teams. The <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20national%20football%20team">UAE</a> qualified for the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> in <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990</a>, along with <a href="Egypt%20national%20football%20team">Egypt</a>. It was the third consecutive World Cup with two Arab nations qualifying, after <a href="Kuwait%20national%20football%20team">Kuwait</a> and <a href="Algeria%20national%20football%20team">Algeria</a> in <a href="1982%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1982</a>, and <a href="Iraq%20national%20football%20team">Iraq</a> and Algeria again in <a href="1986%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1986</a>. The UAE has won the <a href="Gulf%20Cup%20of%20Nations">Gulf Cup Championship</a> twice: the first cup won in January 2007 held in <a href="Abu%20Dhabi">Abu Dhabi</a> and the second in January 2013, held in <a href="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>. The country hosted the <a href="2019%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup">2019 AFC Asian Cup</a>. The UAE team went all the way to the semi-finals, where they were defeated by the eventual champions, <a href="Qatar%20national%20football%20team">Qatar</a>.
Cricket.
<a href="Cricket">Cricket</a> is one of the most popular sports in the UAE, largely because of the expatriate population from the <a href="SAARC">SAARC</a> countries, the United Kingdom, and Australia. The headquarters of the <a href="International%20Cricket%20Council">International Cricket Council</a> (ICC) have been located in the <a href="Dubai%20Sports%20City">Dubai Sports City</a> complex since 2005, including the <a href="ICC%20Academy">ICC Academy</a> which was established in 2009. There are a number of international cricket venues in the UAE, which are frequently used for international tournaments and "neutral" bilateral series due to the local climate and Dubai's status as a transport hub. Notable international tournaments hosted by the UAE have included the <a href="2014%20Under-19%20Cricket%20World%20Cup">2014 Under-19 Cricket World Cup</a>, the <a href="2021%20ICC%20Men%27s%20T20%20World%20Cup">2021 ICC Men's T20 World Cup</a>, and three editions of the <a href="Asia%20Cup">Asia Cup</a> (<a href="1984%20Asia%20Cup">1984</a>, <a href="1995%20Asia%20Cup">1995</a> and <a href="2018%20Asia%20Cup">2018</a>). Notable grounds include the <a href="Sharjah%20Cricket%20Association%20Stadium">Sharjah Cricket Association Stadium</a> in <a href="Sharjah">Sharjah</a>, <a href="Sheikh%20Zayed%20Cricket%20Stadium">Sheikh Zayed Cricket Stadium</a> in <a href="Abu%20Dhabi">Abu Dhabi</a>, and <a href="Dubai%20International%20Cricket%20Stadium">Dubai International Cricket Stadium</a> in Dubai.
The <a href="Emirates%20Cricket%20Board">Emirates Cricket Board</a> (ECB) became a member of the ICC in 1990. The <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20national%20cricket%20team">UAE national cricket team</a> has qualified for the <a href="Cricket%20World%20Cup">Cricket World Cup</a> on two occasions (<a href="1996%20Cricket%20World%20Cup">1996</a> and <a href="2015%20Cricket%20World%20Cup">2015</a>) and the <a href="ICC%20Men%27s%20T20%20World%20Cup">ICC Men's T20 World Cup</a> on one occasion (<a href="2014%20ICC%20World%20Twenty20">2014</a>). The <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20women%27s%20national%20cricket%20team">national women's team</a> is similarly one of the strongest associate teams in Asia, notably participating in the <a href="2018%20ICC%20Women%27s%20World%20Twenty20%20Qualifier">2018 ICC Women's World Twenty20 Qualifier</a>.
Following the <a href="2009%20attack%20on%20the%20Sri%20Lanka%20national%20cricket%20team">2009 attack on the Sri Lanka national cricket team</a>, the UAE served as the "de facto" home of the <a href="Pakistan%20national%20cricket%20team">Pakistan national cricket team</a> for nearly a decade, as well as hosting the <a href="Pakistan%20Super%20League">Pakistan Super League</a>. The UAE has also hosted one full edition of <a href="Indian%20Premier%20League">Indian Premier League</a> (IPL) in 2020 and two partial editions of the <a href="Indian%20Premier%20League">Indian Premier League</a> (IPL) In 2014 and 2021 .
Education.
The <a href="education">education system</a> through secondary level is monitored by the Ministry of Education in all emirates except Abu Dhabi, where it falls under the authority of the <a href="Abu%20Dhabi%20Education%20Council">Abu Dhabi Education Council</a>. It consists of <a href="primary%20school">primary school</a>s, <a href="middle%20school">middle school</a>s and <a href="High%20Schools">high schools</a>. The public schools are government-funded and the curriculum is created to match the United Arab Emirates' development goals. The medium of instruction in the public school is Arabic with emphasis on English as a second language. There are also many private schools which are internationally accredited. <a href="Public%20school%20%28government%20funded%29">Public schools</a> in the country are free for citizens of the UAE, while the fees for private schools vary.
The higher education system is monitored by the Ministry of Higher Education. The ministry also is responsible for admitting students to its <a href="undergraduate%20education">undergraduate</a> institutions. The adult literacy rate in 2015 was 93.8%.
The UAE has shown a strong interest in improving education and research. Enterprises include the establishment of the <a href="CERT%20Group%20of%20Companies">CERT</a> Research Centres and the <a href="Masdar%20Institute%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology">Masdar Institute of Science and Technology</a> and Institute for Enterprise Development. According to the QS Rankings, the top-ranking universities in the country are the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates%20University">United Arab Emirates University</a> (421–430th worldwide), <a href="Khalifa%20University">Khalifa University</a> (441–450th worldwide), the <a href="American%20University%20of%20Sharjah">American University of Sharjah</a> (431–440th) and <a href="University%20of%20Sharjah">University of Sharjah</a> (551–600th worldwide). United Arab Emirates was ranked 34th in the <a href="Global%20Innovation%20Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2020, up from 36th in 2019.
Demographics.
According to an estimate by the World Bank, the UAE's population in 2020 stood at 9,890,400. Immigrants accounted for 88.52% while Emiratis made up the remaining 11.48%. This unique imbalance is due to the country's exceptionally high <a href="net%20migration%20rate">net migration rate</a> of 21.71, the <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20net%20migration%20rate">world's highest</a>. UAE citizenship is very difficult to obtain other than by <a href="filiation">filiation</a> and only granted under very special circumstances.
The UAE is ethnically diverse. The five most populous nationalities in the emirates of Dubai, Sharjah, and Ajman are Indian (25%), Pakistani (12%), Emirati (9%), Bangladeshi (7%), and Filipino (5%). Immigrants from Europe, Australia, Northern America and Latin America make up 500,000 of the population. More than 100,000 British nationals live in the country. The rest of the population are from other <a href="Arab%20World">Arab states</a>.
About 88% of the population of the United Arab Emirates is urban. The average <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20life%20expectancy">life expectancy</a> was 76.7 in 2012, higher than for any other Arab country. With a male/female <a href="human%20sex%20ratio">sex ratio</a> of 2.2 males for each female in the total population and 2.75 to 1 for the 15–65 <a href="Demographic%20profile">age group</a>, the UAE's <a href="Gender%20mortality%20differentials">gender imbalance</a> is second highest in the world after Qatar.
Religion.
<a href="Islam">Islam</a> is the largest and the official <a href="state%20religion">state religion</a> of the UAE. The government follows a policy of tolerance toward other religions and rarely interferes in the religious activities of non-Muslims.
There are more <a href="Sunni">Sunni</a> than <a href="Shiite">Shia</a> Muslims in the United Arab Emirates, and 85% of the Emirati population are Sunni Muslims. The vast majority of the remainder 15% are Shia Muslims, who are concentrated in the <a href="Emirate%20of%20Dubai">Emirates of Dubai</a> and <a href="Emirate%20of%20Sharjah">Sharjah</a>. Although no official statistics are available for the breakdown between Sunni and Shia Muslims among noncitizen residents, media estimates suggest less than 20% of the noncitizen Muslim population are Shia. <a href="Sheikh%20Zayed%20Mosque">Sheikh Zayed Mosque</a> in Abu Dhabi is the largest mosque in the country and a major tourist attraction. <a href="Ibadi">Ibadi</a> is common among Omanis in the UAE, while <a href="Sufi">Sufi</a> influences exist as well.
<a href="Roman%20Catholicism%20in%20the%20United%20Arab%20Emirates">Roman Catholics</a> and <a href="Protestantism%20in%20the%20United%20Arab%20Emirates">Protestants</a> form significant proportions of the Christian minority. The country has at least 45 churches. Many Christians in the United Arab Emirates are of Asian, African, and European origin, along with fellow Middle Eastern countries such as Lebanon, Syria, and Egypt. The United Arab Emirates forms part of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Vicariate%20Apostolic%20of%20Southern%20Arabia">Apostolic Vicariate of Southern Arabia</a> and the Vicar Apostolic Bishop <a href="Paul%20Hinder">Paul Hinder</a> is based in <a href="Abu%20Dhabi">Abu Dhabi</a>.
There is a small <a href="Jews">Jewish</a> community in the United Arab Emirates. There is only one known <a href="synagogue">synagogue</a>, in <a href="Dubai">Dubai</a>, which has been open since 2008. The synagogue also welcomes visitors. As of 2019, according to Rabbi <a href="Marc%20Schneier">Marc Schneier</a> of the <a href="Foundation%20for%20Ethnic%20Understanding">Foundation for Ethnic Understanding</a>, it is estimated that there are about 150 families to 3,000 Jews who live and worship freely in the UAE.
South Asians in the United Arab Emirates constitute the largest ethnic group in the country. Over 2 million Indian migrants (mostly from the southern states of <a href="Kerala">Kerala</a>, <a href="Andhra%20Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a>, <a href="Kanara">Coastal Karnataka</a> and <a href="Tamil%20Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>) are estimated to be living in the UAE. There is currently only one Hindu temple in the UAE in Dubai, the <a href="Hindu%20Temple%2C%20Dubai">Hindu Temple, Dubai</a> (referred to locally as Shiva and Krishna Mandir) located in Dubai. Another temple, the <a href="BAPS%20Hindu%20Mandir%20Abu%20Dhabi">BAPS Hindu Mandir Abu Dhabi</a> is a Hindu temple that is being built by the <a href="BAPS%20Swaminarayan%20Sanstha">BAPS Swaminarayan Sanstha</a>n in Abu Dhabi.
Other religions also exist in the United Arab Emirates, including <a href="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>, <a href="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD%20Faith">Baháʼís</a> and <a href="Druze">Druze</a>.
The UAE Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Co-operation, <a href="Abdullah%20bin%20Zayed%20Al%20Nahyan">Abdullah bin Zayed</a>, announced in 2019 the design and construction plan of the <a href="Abrahamic%20Family%20House">Abrahamic Family House</a>, which will serve as an interfaith complex that houses a <a href="synagogue">synagogue</a>, <a href="mosque">mosque</a>, and a <a href="Church%20%28building%29">church</a> on <a href="Saadiyat%20Island">Saadiyat Island</a> in <a href="Abu%20Dhabi">Abu Dhabi</a>.
Languages.
<a href="Arabic%20language">Arabic</a> is the national language of the United Arab Emirates. The <a href="Gulf%20Arabic">Gulf dialect</a> of Arabic is spoken natively by Emirati people. The area was occupied by the British until 1971 and, with many expatriates resident, English is the primary "<a href="lingua%20franca">lingua franca</a>" in the UAE. Consequently, a knowledge of English is a requirement when applying for most local jobs.
Health.
The life expectancy at birth in the UAE is at 76.96 years. <a href="Cardiovascular%20disease">Cardiovascular disease</a> is the principal cause of death in the UAE, constituting 28% of total deaths; other major causes are <a href="accident">accident</a>s and <a href="injury">injuries</a>, <a href="Cancer">malignancies</a>, and <a href="congenital%20disorder">congenital anomalies</a>. According to <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20Body%20Mass%20Index%20%28BMI%29%23WHO%20Data%20on%20Prevalence%20of%20Obesity%20%28BMI%20above%2030%29%20%282016%29">World Health Organisation data from 2016</a>, 34.5% of adults in the UAE are clinically <a href="Obesity">obese</a>, with a <a href="body%20mass%20index">body mass index</a> (BMI) score of 30 or more.
In February 2008, the Ministry of Health unveiled a five-year health strategy for the public health sector in the northern emirates, which fall under its purview and which, unlike Abu Dhabi and Dubai, do not have separate healthcare authorities. The strategy focuses on unifying healthcare policy and improving access to healthcare services at reasonable cost, at the same time reducing dependence on overseas treatment. The ministry plans to add three hospitals to the current 14, and 29 primary healthcare centres to the current 86. Nine were scheduled to open in 2008.
The introduction of mandatory <a href="health%20insurance">health insurance</a> in Abu Dhabi for <a href="expatriate">expatriate</a>s and their dependents was a major driver in reform of healthcare policy. Abu Dhabi nationals were brought under the scheme from 1 June 2008 and Dubai followed for its government employees. Eventually, under federal law, every Emirati and expatriate in the country will be covered by compulsory health insurance under a unified mandatory scheme.
The country has benefited from medical tourists from all over the <a href="Cooperation%20Council%20for%20the%20Arab%20States%20of%20the%20Gulf">Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf</a>. The UAE attracts <a href="medical%20tourism">medical tourists</a> seeking <a href="cosmetic%20surgery">cosmetic surgery</a> and advanced procedures, cardiac and spinal surgery, and dental treatment, as health services have higher standards than other Arab countries in the Persian Gulf.
